title: Effective bike advocacy in the face of declining city budgets

last_post.content:
Things I had success doing when my city was spending zero dollars on bike infrastructure:

1. Creating & printing a bike map
2. Removing "No Bikes" signs
3. Installing public bike racks
4. Organizing cyclists
5. Planning bike lanes-- some got included in long-term plans
6. Convincing the city to ask the DOT for a "complete streets" approach on a state road
7. Putting "Complete Streets" in long term plans.

Tips are shared here:
https://mark.stosberg.com/effective-bike-advocacy-in-the-face-of-declining-city-budgets/?mtm_campaign=masto&mtm_kwd=bikes

#BikeAdvocacy

"What should I measure when the CEO asks for engineering metrics?" is probably the most frequently recurring eng leadership question, and connects into a larger, somewhat nebulous topic: how should you measure engineering organizations?

The biggest challenge with answering this question directly imo is that there are a number of different stakeholders who all want very different things. Literal answers anchor on one stakeholders rather than solving for whole set.

https://lethain.com/measuring-engineering-organizations/

Die Aufzeichnung ist jetzt online: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=op5aKw0cyrY

"I am not burying myself in a narrow particularism. But neither do I want to lose myself in an emaciated universalism. There are two ways to lose oneself: walled segregation in the particular or dilution in the 'universal'

My conception of the universal is that of a universal enriched by all that is particular, a universal enriched by every particular: the deepening and coexistence of all particulars"

— Aimé Césaire's Letter to Maurice Thorez

https://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/153945859-Aime-Cesaire-Letter-to-Maurice-Thorez-1956.pdf

While discussing the same Q with someone here on mastodon, I realised the dominant nature of academic research is that of continuity right?

There's this assumption that an idea ALWAYS HAS to emerge from continuity of previous social practices

What about discontinuities/deviance tho?

https://mastodon.social/@impactology/109416379312676173

In what scenario is researcher allowed to break from cannon, to discontinue, to deviate. To begin anew?

title: Bonhoeffer’s Theory of Stupidity – Sprouts – Learning Videos – Social Sciences

last_post.content:
#TiL253 (369)
Bonhoeffer’s Stupidity Theory.
Stupidity is harder to deal with than evil.
You can act against evil, but stupidity (in large groups) is much more difficult.
Bonhoeffer was imprisoned and killed by the Nazis in 1945.
But this is very relevant to modern times.
A good explainer:

https://sproutsschools.com/bonhoeffers-theory-of-stupidity/

title: Frustrated Ferromagnetism of Honeycomb Cobaltates: Incommensurate Spirals, Quantum Disordered Phases, and Out-of-Plane Ising Order

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.14053 by Watanabe et. al. Authors show that a sign change of the dominant nearest-neighbor coupling has substantial consequences on the phase diagram of XXZ models with competing interactions beyond the nearest neighbor exchange (important for Co-based d7 honeycomb materials BaCo2(AsO4)2 and BaCo2(PO4)2). Plaquette valence bond crystal changes to a long-range entangled spin liquid phase. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2212_14053

When electronics importer Cara Leon goes missing, private investigator Sam Mujrif is hired by her sister to investigate. Cara is 8 times taller than Sam, but evidence soon points to players much smaller than either of them.

As Sam and his cross-scale colleagues pursue the case, it becomes apparent that Cara’s disappearance is linked to technology with the potential to reshape their whole society, and radically alter the balance of power between the scales.

https://www.gregegan.net/SCALE/SCALE.html

Posting for those who may need to do this.

Fission is in the news, but few recognize that a woman physicist was behind the discovery.

Lise Meitner’s brilliance led to the discovery of nuclear fission. But her long time collaborator Otto Hahn, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry w/o her in 1944, even though she had given the first theoretical explanation.

Albert Einstein called Meitner “our Marie Curie." She also adamantly refused to work on the atomic bomb during WWII. https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201502/physicshistory.cfm #women #history #science #energy

2022

title: FT writers’ predictions for the world in 2023

last_post.content:
Going to the gym 3 times this week won't make up for not having gone all these years.

Taking that one multivitamin before your blood test doesn't matter.

Flossing once before the dentist visit won't do.

And yes, go work out, get your vitamins, floss.

It's the climate problem in a nutshell. It's also what makes questions like these about 1.5°C so frustrating, and yet, what else do we have?

https://www.ft.com/content/9784cc74-1193-4e1b-bf61-8ecaf19f569e

title: uiCA: Accurate Throughput Prediction of Basic Blocks on Recent Intel Microarchitectures

last_post.content:
A mic drop moment in the uiCA paper is when they show that the trivial baseline model

rthroughput = max(instructions / 4, loads / 2, stores)

beats llvm-mca and OSACA by a wide margin and approaches IACA in prediction accuracy, at least on BHive. Of course, this isn't uiCA's actual model (it has a proper pipeline model) but it puts the accuracy of those other tools into perspective. Conversely, it shows how good the baseline model is for napkin estimates.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.14210

#generativeai #generativeart

I deeply loved this game, an absolutely perfect synthesis of story, visual and typographic design, scholarly research, and interactive gameplay. It ends with a long bibliography. It’s one of those works of art that makes me wish I could’ve been involved in its making.

I typically don’t care for point-and-click adventures—the slow pacing and flat art style usually doesn’t work for me—but here those elements are integral to the story. Winter, around Christmastime, is the ideal time to play it.

(In an alternate reality you could play it on the web, but that’s not how the history of gamedev went, so I implore you to borrow an old Windows laptop from a friend if you don’t own an XBox or PC.)

#pentiment #NarrativeGames

https://pentiment.obsidian.net/

I was reading on [[Víctor Jara]] to start the year:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V%C3%ADctor_Jara

I knew from his music that he was a communist and political activist. What I didn't know was that...

> Jara was arrested by the Chilean military shortly after the 11 September 1973 coup led by Augusto Pinochet, which overthrew Allende. He was tortured during interrogations and ultimately shot dead, and his body was thrown out on the street of a shantytown in Santiago.

I just saw this too: https://mastodon.social/@dml@macaw.social/109569708104597833

@PessoaBrain @introspection @roydanroy

Yes, I have the same intuition as @introspection. But mechanistically it’s an active topic of study. One of the papers I mentioned above (https://transformer-circuits.pub/2022/in-context-learning-and-induction-heads/index.html) suggests “induction heads” as the mechanism underlying this phenomenon: “a circuit whose function is to look back over the sequence for previous instances of the current token (call it A), find the token that came after it last time (call it B), and then predict that the same completion will occur again (e.g. forming the sequence [A][B] … [A] → [B]).”

title: California woman claims museum secretly sold her grandma's Nazi-stolen van Gogh

last_post.content:
This new story about the looted Van Gogh that the Metropolitan Museum of Art "deaccessioned" in 1956 is an interesting one.

The family never stood a chance.

"Olive Picking", attributed to Van Gogh, was quietly sold to a Greek shipping magnate who stashed it away for decades. When it popped up at an exhibition in the 21st century the family finally learned where it was.

https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2022-12-18/van-gogh-nazi-stolen-art-8460835.html

#provenance #museum #histodons #glammr #loot #law #restitution #ethics #art #WWII #vangogh

Bodily, a sink-hole casting
One small spell of collapse”

title: Relative velocity | Demonstration of constant speed with a moving trampoline

last_post.content:
A nice empirical demonstration of Galileo's principle of relativity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIMNS0YiHzY

If one replaces the person on the trampoline with a light beam bouncing up and down between two horizontal mirrors, and assumes that the speed of light is \(c\) in every inertial frame, one obtains (from Pythagoras) the well-known 'light clock" thought experiment of Einstein that derives the fact that such clocks slow down by a factor of √(1−𝑣²/𝑐²) when moving at a velocity \(v\).

The standard response is that you need to keep the false positive rate low but, per https://danluu.com/programmer-moneyball/, https://danluu.com/algorithms-interviews/, etc., the false positive and negative rates are both high and I don't see any reason to believe that trendy processes from 20 years ago were worse than today's trendy processes.

I also think that just looking at false positive rate is too simplistic. If we instead use a simple model with great/ok/bad hires, the most productive company I worked for excelled by

title: Shift Happens: A book about keyboards

last_post.content: My friend @mwichary has been working on what will be THE definitive work on keyboards - but is much more than that. It will be genuinely beautiful and genuinely human, because there's no other possible output from Marcin. I'll be backing it. Check it out: https://shifthappens.site/

I have an article, “Ghost Ships,” in the new issue of Logic. It’s about why global shipping runs on paper, the gold rush to change that, and the Middle Passage. I believe it’ll be available openly at some point, but you can buy it in print or digitally now: https://logicmag.io/pivot/ #criticallogistics #criticainfrastructure #logistics #criticaldatastudies

title: The Mexican Transpacific – Vanderbilt University Press

last_post.content: Beginning the year with the sixth book of the Critical Mexican Studies series, which I edit for Vanderbilt University Press: Ignacio López-Calvo’s The Mexican Transpacific, a study of the artistic production of people of Japanese descent in Mexico. As usual, thanks to my editors Gianna Mosser and Zack Gresham for their unending support. The book is available in hardcover, paperback, epub and pdf here: https://www.vanderbiltuniversitypress.com/9780826504937/the-mexican-transpacific/

Incidentally: https://chunkabook.com/

It's a tool for tracking books that you read one chapter at a time. Textbooks, anthologies, that kind of thing. It's not DONE, but I'm done with it for at least the next 18 hours.

I can’t stop thinking about how difficult communication is sometimes. And as a result I keep thinking of JFK’s most famous (to me) quote:

“There’s always some son of a bitch who doesn’t get the word.”

https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/06/missile_crisis_excerpt200806

Phil Ting's #FreedomToWalk Act is now law in California. You can cross the street anywhere as long as you're not creating a hazard.

#Jaywalking, the fake "crime" created by automobile industry lobbying to blame victims of #TrafficViolence, no longer exists in California.

Enjoy your freedom to walk! https://ktla.com/news/california/new-law-allows-californians-to-legally-jaywalk/

title: Mastodon—and the pros and cons of moving beyond Big Tech gatekeepers

If, like me, you've been curious about the history of the #Fediverse and how #ActivityPub works since you migrated to #Mastodon from #Twitter, this is a fantastic article on those subjects which includes a very easy-to-understand explanation by @cwebber, who was the lead author of the 2018 ActivityPub standard 👇

https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/12/mastodon-highlights-pros-and-cons-of-moving-beyond-big-tech-gatekeepers/

RT @BerkouwerS
PSA for North Americans (because airlines *hate* sharing this info):

If you are flying from the EU to the Americas, even with a US airline, you are entitled to EUR 600 (!) compensation if your flight is delayed by 3+ hours. Send this form to the airline:
https://transport.ec.europa.eu/system/files/2022-11/eu_complaint_form_en.pdf
